titleStmt.title: Exceeding joyfull nevvs from Lincoln-shire. Or The resolution of the gentry and commonalty, inhabiting in the county of Lineoln [sic], concerning the Kings most Excellent Majesty, and the high court of Parliament. Also joyfull nevves from Leicester declaring how Mr Henry Hastings was taken prisoner by the High-Sheriffe of the said county, on Sunday, August 14. 1642. Whereunto is annexed the resolution of the Lords and Commons assembled in this present Parliament, concerning the Kings most Excellent Majesty. Ordered that this be printed and published. Joh. Browne, Cler. Parl.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: EXCEEDING JOYFULL NEWS FROM LINCOLN-SHIRE.
OR The Re≈øolution of the Gentry and Commonalty, inhabiting in the County of Lincoln, concerning the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, and the High Court of Parliament.
ALSO JOYFVLL NEVVES FROM LEICESTER Declaring how Mr Henry Ha≈øtings was taken pri≈øoner by the High-Sheriffe of the ≈øaid County, on Sunday, Augu≈øt 14. 1642.
Whereunto is annexed the Re≈øolution of the Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in this pre≈øent Parliament, concerning the Kings mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øty.
Ordered that this be printed and publi≈øhed.
LONDON, Printed for Henry Fowler. Aug. 17. 1642.

div.head: Joyfull Newes FROM Lincolne-≈øhire.
div.p: THe Inhabitants of the Countie of Lincolne, having by their Petitions to the high Court of Parliament, declared their hearty affections to them, de≈øiring them to goe on with confidence, promi≈øing them that their Lives, e≈øtates, and all they could command, ≈øhould be laid downe at their Feet.

Likewi≈øe their Petition pre≈øented to his Maje≈øtie at Yorke, wherein they humbly intreated his Maje≈øty to returne to his Parliament, declaring the great mi≈øery, & apparent troubles that were like to en≈øue, and fall upon this Kingdome, if his Maje≈øty ≈øhould any longer deny his gratious pre≈øence and Royall a≈ø≈øent to his high Court of Parliament, wherein they declared the depth of their affections to the Parliament, and their earne≈øt de≈øire
„Äà‚óä„Äâ pre≈øerve the peace of the Kingdome.

Neverthele≈ø≈øe they having received an An≈øwer to their Petition, were reviled by the Cavaliers, and called Round-heads, with other abu≈øes not fit to be mentioned. At their returne from Yorke they by order of the Committee of Parliament a≈ø≈øembled to put the Ordinance of Militia in execution, where there were a≈ø≈øembled many thou≈øands to the great admiration and not little ≈øati≈øfaction of the Lieutenants of the Shire that were appointed by the Parliament to ≈øee the ≈øaid Ordinance put in execution.

Likewi≈øe they then gave ≈øuch large te≈øtimonies of his love and obedience to the Parliament, that the Committee thought it nece≈ø≈øary to give imformation thereof to the Hou≈øe, who returned them thankes for the ≈øame, animating them on to a continuance in the ≈øame duty.

Which they had great rea≈øon to do, there being at that very in≈øtant Officers appointed by His Maje≈øty to put the commi≈ø≈øion of Aray in execution: Neverthele≈ø≈øe, though His Maje≈øties Officers had put up the Proclamation concerning His Maje≈øties di≈øavowing the ordinance of the Militia, withall giving ≈øtrict command in His Maje≈øties name, that they ≈øhould not yeeld obedience to the ≈øaid Ordinance, they ≈øtill with chearfulne≈ø≈øe pur≈øued in the due execution of the ≈øame.

His Maje≈øty finding that his expectation was made fru≈øtrate and that he could not prevail with
his officers (being councelled thereto by the Lord Mowbray) was re≈øolved to goe in per≈øon to put the commi≈ø≈øion of Aray in execution.
Where being arived, he by his ≈øpeciall command cau≈øed the gentry and cominalty of the ≈øaid Countie to be ≈øummoned, who according to their Loyalty and Allegiance obeyed His Maje≈øties command.
By rea≈øon of which they have undergone many cen≈øures, ≈øome calling them Turne-coats, and many other ignominious names.
For which cau≈øe they thought it convenient to declare their Re≈øolution concerning their obedience to His Maje≈øty, and their duty to the Parliament.

For their obedience to His Maje≈øties commands, they declare that it ≈øtood not with their loyalties to ≈øtand in flat oppo≈øition to His Maje≈øties commands, (His Maje≈øty commanding nothing which intrenched upon the Peace of the Kingdome, or the priviledge of Parliament) Withall they doe declare, that if His Maje≈øty ≈øhall command them, they will march with him, and obey his ju≈øt commands, as loyall and obedient Subjects.

But likewi≈øe they are re≈øolved ≈øo farre to pre≈øerve their duty to the Parliament, that if his Maje≈øty, in his owne per≈øon, or by his mini≈øters, ≈øhall command them to put any thing in execution again≈øt the Parliament, or imploy any others
of His Maje≈øties Forces in any ≈øuch de≈øign; that then they will not onely forbeare the performance of any ≈øuch act them≈øelves, but al≈øo hazard then lives in oppo≈øing of all ≈øuch as ≈øhall any way indeavour the ≈øame.

Promi≈øing that they ≈øhall no longer wi≈øh a godly neace, a freedome in Religion, nor the ≈øweet enjoyment of ought that is good or deare unto them, then they ≈øhall continue faithfull to the commands of the high Court of Parliament.

This is the Re≈øolution of the Gentry and Commonalty of Lincolne≈øhire, which I have publi≈øhed for the ≈øatisfaction of the world, it being related to me by a Gentleman of good worth of the ≈øame County.

Likewi≈øe a Letter was ≈øent from Leice≈øter to a Merchant of this City, declaring how Ma≈øter Ha≈øtings with a Troop of Cavaliers went up again≈øt the High Sheriffe of the ≈øaid County, with an intent to have burnt his hou≈øe; but the High Sheriffe having notice thereof, ≈øummoned ≈øome Troops of Hor≈øe, which were rai≈øed ≈øince the≈øe troubles began in the Kingdome; and three miles from Langborough, fell upon him, killed eight of his men, and tooke him, and ≈øome other of his Cavaliers: which he having done, ≈øent him to the City of Leice≈øter. But on the way Colonel Lunsford met with him, having a ≈øtrong party, and wor≈øted them, taking the ≈øaid Ha≈øtings
away before the Countrey could come in to their re≈øcue. Neverthele≈ø≈øe they were forced to fly as fa≈øt as their legs could carry them.

Likewi≈øe it is re≈øolved upon the Que≈øtion by the Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, that in ca≈øe any Force be brought out of one County into another County of this Kingdome, to di≈øturbe the peace of the Kingdome, that the Lord Lieutenants and the Deputy Lieutenants of the Counties adjoyning, be required to give aid and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to the ≈øaid Lord Lieutenants or Deputy Lieutenants requiring the ≈øame, &c.

div.head: The Parliaments RESOL∆≤TION, Concerning the Kings mo≈øt Excellent MAJESTY.
div.p:
THE Lords and Commons to witne≈ø≈øe their con≈øtant and un≈øhaken loyalty and affection to his Maje≈øty, do ≈øolemnly declare that if his Maje≈øty ≈øhall immediately disband
all his Forces; and be plea≈øed to abandon all tho≈øe wicked Coun≈øells, and leave them to condigne puni≈øhment and returne and hearken to the whol≈øome advice of his great Coun≈øell, they will really endeavour to make both his Maje≈øty and his Po≈øterity, as great, rich, and potent, as much beloved at home and feared abroad, as any Prince that ever ≈øwayed this Scepter, which is their firm and con≈øtant Re≈øolution.
ORdered by the Lords and Commons in Parliament, that this Declaration be forthwith Printed and publi≈øhed.

closer.signed: Hen. El≈øyng Cler. Parl. Do. Com.
